channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã716 ‚Äî December 12, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Boa v0.20: An Alternative JavaScript Compiler ‚Äî Under development for several years, Boa has a few missions: be a Rust ECMAScript implementation, be easy to embed in Rust projects, and be a fast, safe JS engine overall. v0.20 sees a bump up to 89.92% compliance in the Test262 suite, improves Temporal support, adds Atomics.pause, and more. This is no toy¬†engine.

Boa Developers

React v19 Now Stable ‚Äî First teased in a February 2024 update, React 19 has been in beta for 8 months, so there‚Äôs already a wealth of content about it, from the React 19 upgrade guide or an explanation of its compiler to cheat sheets and Vercel‚Äôs roundup of what‚Äôs new in React¬†19.

The React Team

Build with Gemini at Lightning Speeds ‚Äî With the largest context window available, Google Gemini provides JavaScript developers multimodal processing of images, videos and text. Start using Google Gemini in minutes using AI¬†Studio.

Google Gemini sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • üéÆ If you ever do any game development with JavaScript, it's time to take the Gamedev.JS Survey 2024. If you don't, you can head to JS13KGames and enjoy other people's creative efforts instead¬†:-)

  • Apple has released Safari 18.2 which introduces a few enhancements to JavaScript support including Float16Array, more methods for Uint8Array, Promise.try, RegExp.escape, and more.

  • Did you know Douglas Crockford is Not Your Dad? Well, at least when it comes to putting comments in JSON..

RELEASES:

  • VS Code November Release ‚Äì Now when you copy and paste JS/TS code, VS Code can add imports for the pasted code.

  • Next.js 15.1 ‚Äì The popular React framework gets full React 19¬†support.

  • Node v23.4.0 (Current) ‚Äì Say hello to assert.partialDeepStrictEqual and --trace-env for tracing environment variable¬†usage.

  • Sheriff v25 - Opinionated TypeScript-first ESLint configuration. Now supporting ESLint¬†v9.

  • Undici 7.1 ‚Äì HTTP/2 support now marked as stable in the Node.js HTTP¬†library.

  • pnpm 9.15, Dependency Cruiser 16.8, Redux Toolkit 2.5, YouTube.js 12.2

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

The State of Node.js Performance in 2024 ‚Äî A thorough set of benchmarks covering recent performance advancements made in Node.js. The improvements between Node 18 and 20 up to version 22 might surprise you - it‚Äôs clear the team has put a lot of work into this¬†area.

Gonzaga and Parody (NodeSource)

How to Reduce TTFB? ‚Äî High "time to first byte" affects web vitals. Learn to identify and fix issues slowing your¬†TTFB.

Sentry sponsor

Publishing a Simple Client-Side JS Package to npm with GitHub¬†Actions ‚Äî As part of the process of building Prompts.js, a new library for creating simple await-able alternatives to alert(), confirm() and prompt(), Simon wanted to make it easy to publish as an npm package¬†too.

Simon Willison

How to Build a SolidJS App with Deno ‚Äî SolidJS is a declarative library for creating user interfaces that emphasizes fine-grained reactivity and minimal overhead and it plays well with¬†Deno.

Andy Jiang

Get Cooking! Generative AI with MongoDB ‚Äî See how MongoDB, the world‚Äôs most popular document database, integrates with RAG pipelines and cutting-edge AI¬†agents.

MongoDB sponsor

üìÑ Building Your Own npm create Package ‚Äì You'll have seen (or used) various scaffolding tools using this technique. (A Different) Alex Chan

üìÑ What We Learned Migrating From Webpack to Vite Roman Zaynetdinov

üìÑ Understanding the Browser's Main Thread Amrik Malhans

üì∫ An Honest Review of TanStack Start vs Next.js Ankita Kulkarni

üìÑ How React Compiler Performs on Real Code Nadia Makarevich

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

Termo: An Easy to Use Terminal Control for Websites ‚Äî If you want to offer a terminal emulator style feature on your site (maybe for advanced users, to enhance your docs, or even just as an easter egg), Termo enhances Xterm.js and presents a slick¬†experience.

Raj Nandan Sharma

üñºÔ∏è¬†wasm-vips: libvips Image Processing via WebAssembly ‚Äî libvips is an efficient image processing library written in C. This build offers an isomorphic route to using it in the browser, as well as Node and Deno, all thanks to WebAssembly. (There's an interactive demo¬†here.)

Kleis Auke Wolthuizen

Looking for a DIY Survey Solution? SurveyJS Has You Covered ‚Äî Build, customize, and store surveys with ease. Total data control, JSON-driven, no backend restrictions‚Äîintegrates into any JavaScript¬†app.

SurveyJS sponsor

Civet 0.9: Code More with Less Using a TypeScript Superset ‚Äî Two years old and well maintained, Civet offers an interesting approach. Think JavaScript but with Python style indentation, chained comparisons, built-in JSX, & more. This example alone shows off the potential for tighter, easier-to-write¬†code.

Daniel X Moore and Contributors

Rockpack 5.0: An Alternative React App Starter ‚Äî A Create React App-style tool aiming to get React project setup time as low as possible, complete with server side rendering support, bundling, linting and testing. GitHub¬†repo.

Alex Sergey

jsesc: Get a Stringified, ASCII-Safe Representation of Any Data ‚Äî Think JSON.stringify() but instead it returns JavaScript meaning it can support things like maps, sets, and BigInts.

Mathias Bynens

  • üìä Perspective 3.2 (above) ‚Äì Data visualization and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly where it can be used from¬†JavaScript. Their homepage shows it off well with a live example. Now supports newline delimited JSON¬†(ndjson).

  • ‚òéÔ∏é International Telephone Input 25.2 ‚Äì Component for entering and validating international phone¬†numbers. Vue, React, and¬†vanilla.

  • debug 4.4 ‚Äì Tiny debugging utility modelled after Node.js core's debugging¬†approach (but for the browser¬†too).

  • ExpressoTS 3.0 ‚Äì TypeScript framework for server-side Node.js¬†apps.

  • InversifyJS 6.2 ‚Äì Inversion of control container for¬†JavaScript.

  • üìä ApexCharts 4.2 ‚Äì Popular JS charting library. (Demos.)

  • Vue3-Carousel 0.9 ‚Äì Customizable, lightweight Vue 3 carousel component.

  • html-react-parser 5.2 ‚Äì Isomorphic HTML to React¬†parser.

  • AlaSQL.js 4.6 ‚Äì Isomorphic JavaScript SQL¬†database.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards and¬†others.

If your work leans more towards the frontend, be sure to check out the latest issue of Frontend Focus, our sister newsletter focused on all things¬†browser-side.

item.title: „ÄêA 2024 JavaScript retrospective„Äë2024 Âπ¥ JavaScript ÂõûÈ°æ
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã717 ‚Äî December 19, 2024

Read on the Web

üéÑ We've made it to the end of 2024! In this issue, we're being reflective, leading with a few news items but then looking at what made 2024 special in the world of JavaScript, and covering some of the biggest things we linked to this year.

Then we're on a Christmas break for two weeks and will be back in your inbox on Friday, January 10, 2025, ‚Äî yes, we're moving back to Fridays for 2025!¬†We hope you have a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.
__
Peter Cooper and the Cooperpress team

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JavaScript 2024 Results ‚Äî We recently encouraged you to take the annual State of JavaScript survey; the results are now out. 14,015 folks took part and we get to see what language features folks are using, experiences with popular libraries, build tool popularity, AI preferences, popular podcasts, runtime usage, and perhaps controversially, how more JavaScript developers are using TypeScript than not. There‚Äôs a lot to dig through¬†here.

Sacha Greif

Complete Intro to React v9: New Project, Modern¬†Stack ‚Äî Join Brian Holt in building a pizza delivery app from scratch. Master hooks, TanStack Router, testing, and React 19 features in this comprehensive guide to modern React development. No prior React experience¬†needed.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • ü•á JetBrains' recent State of Developer Ecosystem report shows that JavaScript is "the most used programming language", reports InfoWorld's Paul Krill. The report also claims "despite its gains, TypeScript will not replace¬†JavaScript".

  • üóìÔ∏è We've just finished 2024 wrap ups in the latest issue of Node Weekly and React Status, if you want more depth into those¬†topics.

  • ü§ñ GitHub has made its Copilot AI assistant available for free (with limits). We also learn that there are now 150 million developers on GitHub.

  • üáµüá± If you're in Poland, consider heading along to the next WarsawJS meetup on January 8. Esteemed Polish computer scientist Andrzej Blikle will be speaking, amongst¬†others.

  • ü§ñ Vercel is running a State of AI developer survey they'd like you to take.

RELEASES:

  • JerryScript 3.0 ‚Äì 'Ultra lightweight' JS engine for IoT/embedded use cases with full ES 5.1 compliance and 84% Test262¬†conformance.

  • ü§ñ Transformers.js v3.2 ‚Äì Run machine learning models in the browser. Now supporting Moonshine real-time speech recognition and Phi 3.5¬†Vision.

  • Bun 1.1.39 and 1.1.40 ‚Äì The fast JS runtime gets a human-readble lockfile format, fetch bodies can now be streams, and Node compatibility¬†improves.

  • Prisma 6.1 ‚Äì Popular ORM for Node.js and¬†TypeScript. Tracing is now¬†GA.

  • pnpm 10.0 RC 0, ESLint v9.17.0, Recharts 2.15

Introducing Authentication Support for React Router ‚Äî Add authentication and authorization to your React Router application in minutes with pre-built components and¬†more.

Clerk sponsor

üìÑ Introducing TanStack Start ‚Äì A new full-stack React framework powered by TanStack Router. Adam Rackis

üìÑ How to Create Multi-Step Forms with Vanilla JS and CSS Fatuma Abdullaho

üìÑ Summarizing Text with Transformers.js Raymond Camden

üóìÔ∏è¬†What Happened to JavaScript in 2024

The JavaScript world has had a busy 2024, as you'd expect for the world's most used programming language (despite the threat of being split into two). We looked back over the year and remembered some things that occurred:

  • In February, the React team posted a mega 'React Labs' update which framed the whole of React's year, explaining the goals of the React Compiler and the eventual React 19 release (which went stable this month).

  • Alternative JavaScript runtimes had a great 2024, particularly Bun which introduced Bun Shell, Windows support and the ability to compile and run native C from JavaScript. Deno had a big year too, with the release of Deno 2 which included stronger Node.js/npm compatibility and package management tooling. Other systems continuing to progress this year include Boa JS, QuickJS, and Porffor.

  • Over at TC39, lots of language proposals were advanced this year (and that's just a sample ‚Äì here's some more!). The ES2025 future is bright.

Boost Semantic Search with MongoDB Atlas Vector Search ‚Äî Create embeddings, index them, and run semantic queries‚Äîjust follow the quick start¬†tutorial.

MongoDB sponsor

  • Deno decided to take the JavaScript trademark fight to Oracle and formally filed a petition with the USPTO to cancel it. We hope to see some developments here in 2025, but Oracle are prepared to defend¬†it.

  • Not content to merely work on an edge platform, JS runtime, and fight Oracle, Deno also unveiled JSR, a fresh attempt at providing a registry for JavaScript¬†packages.

  • There were lots of big releases generally for major JavaScript projects including Svelte v5, Node.js v23.0, Astro 5.0, TypeScript 5.7, Vite 6.0, React Native 0.76, Next.js 15, React Router v7, Rspack 1.0, Vue.js 3.5, and Angular 19.

  • The OG of JavaScript libraries jQuery 4.0 went into beta too! We keep our fingers crossed for a jQuery 4.0 final release in 2025..¬†;-)

ü•á¬†Our Top Items of 2024

Next up is a walk through the top items we included in 2024, ordered by level of reader engagement. No editorial judgments here ‚Äì these are the things you cared about most:

1.¬†console.delight ‚Äî By far our most popular link of the year with over 20,000 clicks(!) ‚Äì but who doesn't use and love console.log? This post showed us how in the browser console it's not merely for printing plain text, but can be used to render things like SVGs and HTML.

Zach Saucier

2.¬†JavaScript Visualized: Promise Execution ‚Äî A well-diagrammed article coupled with an (optional) 8 minute video that went into how promises work under the hood. Hugely popular as most of Lydia's content tends to¬†be.

Lydia Hallie

WorkOS: Sell to Enterprises with a Few Lines of Code ‚Äî The modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and FGA in minutes instead of¬†months.

WorkOS sponsor

3.¬†Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework? ‚Äî Despite being five years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity in 2023 and 2024, partly due to framework fatigue, but also as its simple HTML-oriented approach to adding functionality to pages appeals to a diverse group of developers. v2.0 landed in June.

Alexander Petros

4.¬†Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: What‚Äôs New? ‚Äî In June, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript spec, officially making it a standard. As with ES2023, it was a reasonably small step forward, but Dr. Axel rounded up what was¬†new.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

5.¬†JavaScript's ??= Operator: Default Values Made Simple ‚Äî The ??= nullish coalescing assignment operator snuck into JavaScript a few years ago via ES2021 and has been broadly supported almost everywhere for ages. Trevor showed off how it can tighten up your¬†assignments.

Trevor I. Lasn

6.¬†Eloquent JavaScript: The Fourth Edition ‚Äî Coming several years after the third edition, the latest version of what is, perhaps, the best ‚Äòall rounder‚Äô book for learning JavaScript arrived in March ‚Äúadjusted to the realities of 2024 and generally touched¬†up.‚Äù

Marijn Haverbeke

7.¬†33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know ‚Äî A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas it‚Äôs worth understanding well, including types, closures, equality, scope, and different¬†engines.

Leonardo Maldonado

8.¬†How Google Handles JavaScript In Its Indexing Process ‚Äî At one point if you wanted Google to index your content it needed to be directly written in HTML and not dynamically rendered with JavaScript. Things have since changed, of course, but by how¬†much?

Zecchini, Moore, Siddle, Ubl (Vercel)

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards and¬†others.

Hookdeck: An alternative to Amazon API Gateway + Lambda + SQS. With local dev, debugging, and observability¬†built-in.

ü§ó Many thanks for reading JavaScript Weekly in 2024, sending in your links, and generally supporting us. We look forward to seeing you again early next year. Remember, we're moving back to Fridays (long term subscribers may remember we used to go out on Fridays for the first several years) so we'll be back on Friday,¬†January¬†10.

item.title: „ÄêOracle engages its lawyers and JavaScript turns 29„ÄëOracle ËÅòËØ∑ÂæãÂ∏àÔºåJavaScript Â∑≤Êª° 29 Â≤Å
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã715 ‚Äî December 5, 2024

Read on the Web

üóìÔ∏è If you missed last week's issue, don't worry, it didn't exist ‚Äì we took a week off for Thanksgiving! We're now back all the way through to the Christmas break :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript‚Ñ¢ Weekly

Deno v. Oracle: Cancelling the JavaScript Trademark ‚Äî Did you know Oracle formally owns the ‚ÄòJavaScript‚Äô trademark? There have been a few efforts to change this over the years but Oracle isn‚Äôt listening, so the Deno team formally filed a petition to cancel the trademark.

Deno

‚öñÔ∏è And, as of this week, it looks like Oracle is lawyering up to defend it [PDF].

üéÇ¬†JavaScript Turns 29 Years Old ‚Äî If you‚Äôre wondering why Oracle has the JavaScript trademark, it's because Sun owned the name and Oracle acquired Sun (which is also why it owns Java). As someone who was posting inane questions in comp.lang.javascript in 1996, this news makes me feel old ‚Äì no-one could have anticipated what JavaScript would be¬†today.

Netscape and Sun Microsystems

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps ‚Äî SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demos¬†now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Astro 5.0: The Web Framework for Content-Driven Sites ‚Äî Astro has taken the front-end world by storm and v5.0 keeps up its rapid pace of development. Content Layer makes it easy to load content from any source and Server Islands can combine cached, static content with dynamic content. There‚Äôs now a type-safe way to manage environment variables and Vite 6 is along for the ride too. You can play with Astro 5 using the astro.new site.

The Astro Team

Take the State of JavaScript 2024 Survey ‚Äî Each year, Devographics runs a popular survey to see what JS features and tools you know about, use, and love/hate. It‚Äôs structured such that you can learn something just from taking it and the results are always interesting (see 2023‚Äôs). It‚Äôs open for a few more days, despite what the page¬†says. (Or ‚ñ∂Ô∏è watch someone else taking¬†it?)

Devographics

IN BRIEF:

  • npmjs.com has a 'new, streamlined search experience. It's mostly a tweaking of the 'sort' options ‚Äì so take a search like this one for 'svg', you can now sort by recent download counts and dependency¬†levels.

  • TC39 News: Import Sync (explained here) is being promoted to stage 1, Error.isError moves to stage 3, and Intl.DurationFormat moves to stage 4.

  • üéÑ Adrian Roselli has a roundup of development-themed advent calendars for you to enjoy this month, including Advent of TypeScript. 'Tis the¬†season!

  • Porffor is an interesting ahead-of-time JavaScript compiler, now complete with a snazzy new¬†homepage.

  • test262.fyi presents a technical view of how different JS engines fare on the official ECMAScript conformance¬†suite.

RELEASES:

  • TypeScript 5.7 ‚Äì The final release of the typed JavaScript¬†superset.

  • Node.js v22.12.0 (LTS) ‚Äì A noteworthy release as it's the first Node LTS release with require(esm) enabled by¬†default.

  • Radon IDE 1.0 ‚Äì Turn VS Code or Cursor into a fully-fledged React Native¬†IDE.

  • Prisma 6 ‚Äì Powerful Node.js + TypeScript ORM.

  • Vite 6.0, React Router 7.0, Undici 7, ESLint v9.16.0, Meteor.js 3.1, Relay 18.2, Tailwind CSS v4.0 Beta, Redux Toolkit 2.4, Bun 1.1.38, NeutralinoJS 5.5

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

ü§ñ¬†Using Transformers.js for AI in the Browser ‚Äî Transformers.js is a seriously impressive project we link from time to time that lets you run pretrained machine learning models in the browser. Here‚Äôs a practical look at actually playing with it yourself right¬†now.

Raymond Camden

Working with JavaScript's Scheduler API ‚Äî A look at an API only available in Chromium/Edge for now, but that promises a way to prioritize and control task execution in a more refined way than was possible till¬†now.

Trevor I. Lasn

Quokka V2: Deeper Code Insights & Interactive Timeline with New UI ‚Äî The #1 JavaScript scratchpad just got better! Quokka v2 brings a new UI, interactive timeline, and tools for faster¬†prototyping.

Wallaby Team sponsor

üìâ¬†How To Improve 'Interaction to Next Paint' in React Apps ‚Äî Interaction to Next Paint (INP) is a Web performance metric based on the responsiveness of an app to user interactions ‚Äì Google uses it as part of its ranking mechanism. Jacob offers up advice and resources for improving your INP scores in React¬†apps.

Jacob 'Kurt' Gro√ü

How Airtable Scaled TypeScript to Thousands of Projects ‚Äî ‚ÄúToday we have nearly 3000 TypeScript projects. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre sharing our journey to so many projects, and how it reduced our typechecking time by¬†65%.‚Äù

Michael Mitchell (Airtable)

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Building a Teleprompter App in 30 Minutes with AI ‚Äî Building apps with AI powered tools isn‚Äôt unusual nowadays, but if you‚Äôve never been through the process, this is a good look at how it works all the way through to¬†deployment.

Kilian Ekamp

Build Fully Functional Apps in Minutes, Not Months ‚Äî Create, run, edit, and deploy full-stack web apps with¬†Bolt.

StackBlitz sponsor

üì∫ Four Talks from the London TypeScript Meetup ‚Äì All top notch talks. Bloomberg

üìÑ Optimize JS Module Loading with link rel='modulepreload' Trevor I. Lasn

üìÑ Running Your Next.js SSR App on Deno Deploy Orriols and Jiang (Deno)

üìÑ From Jekyll to Astro: An AI-Assisted Migration Kevin London

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

Linkify 4.2: Link Up URLs, Emails, and More in Plain Text ‚Äî Given plain text containing things like links, hashtags, IP addresses, and email addresses, this will generate the correct code to display it on the Web. GitHub¬†repo.

Hypercontext

Skia Canvas 2.0: A 'Browserless' Canvas Environment for Node.js ‚Äî Based on Google‚Äôs Skia engine and offers end results similar to Chrome‚Äôs own canvas system. GPU accelerated and can render images, paths, fonts, shapes, etc. v2.0 adds support for WOFF/WOFF2 fonts, WEBP, and more. GitHub¬†repo.

Christian Swinehart

Introducing <Waitlist/> Mode - A Virtual Queue for Your App ‚Äî Launching a new product but not ready to open it up to everyone yet? Waitlist Sign-up mode is your¬†solution.

Clerk sponsor

Math.js 14.0: An Extensive Math Library ‚Äî Work with complex numbers, fractions, units, matrices, symbolic computation, etc. A long standing library continuing to get frequent updates. GitHub¬†repo.

Jos de Jong

Onlook: 'Figma'-Like Design App for React ‚Äî A new open source, local-first design app (for Windows, Linux & macOS) targeting React apps. Design layouts directly on a live page and instantly write your changes to code. GitHub¬†repo.

On Off Inc.

üïí¬†SpaceTime 7.7: A Lightweight Timezone Library ‚Äî Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. Now updated for 2025. GitHub¬†repo.

Spencer Kelly

BunBuster: A Fast Web and TCP Fuzzer for Brute Forcing Servers ‚Äî As always, use these sorts of things in a responsible way, but it‚Äôs interesting to see tools like this now being built in JavaScript, thanks to Bun‚Äôs speed and ease of distributing¬†binaries.

Tiago Rangel

Kaluma: A Tiny JS Runtime for the Raspberry Pi Pico ‚Äî Can a JS runtime squeeze into 64KB to run on the RP2040-based Raspberry Pi Pico? Kaluma can, even while offering Node.js-style¬†niceties.

Kaluma Project

Todoctor: A Tool to Analyze and Track TODO Comments ‚Äî A CLI tool designed to collect and monitor TODO/FIXME-style comments in JavaScript and TypeScript¬†projects. GitHub repo.

Azat S

üì∞¬†Classifieds

ü™ù Hookdeck: A serverless queue to reliably send, receive, transform, filter, and route events across your event-driven¬†apps.

Meticulous automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Used by Lattice, Bilt Rewards and¬†others.

  • üêç PythonMonkey 1.1 ‚Äì Embed the SpiderMonkey JS engine into Python's¬†VM.

  • nrm 1.5 ‚Äì Fast switching between registries: npm, cnpm, nj,¬†taobao.

  • LogTape 0.8 ‚Äì Simple logging library for all major JS¬†runtimes.

  • Faker 9.3 ‚Äì Generate fabricated data to your heart's¬†content.

  • np 10.1 ‚Äì A better npm¬†publish. Now supports Bun¬†too.

item.title: „ÄêThe projects that shaped JavaScript in 2024„Äë2024 Âπ¥ÂΩ±Âìç JavaScript ÁöÑÈ°πÁõÆ
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã718 ‚Äî January 10, 2025

Read on the Web

üóìÔ∏è Friday is the new Thursday! If you were a JavaScript Weekly reader several years ago, you might remember it always landed on Fridays and after getting caught out by a variety of big news items landing on Thursdays in recent years, we're back¬†;-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

‚≠ê¬†2024's JavaScript Rising Stars ‚Äî It‚Äôs time to fully wave goodbye to 2024, but not before Michael Rambeau‚Äôs annual analysis of which JavaScript projects fared best on GitHub over the past year. Even if you dislike GitHub stars as a metric for anything, this remains a great way to get a feel for the JavaScript ecosystem and see what libraries and tools have mindshare in a variety of niches. A fantastic roundup as¬†always.

Michael Rambeau

A Look at Import Attributes ‚Äî It‚Äôs always a pleasure to see Dr. Axel blogging about JavaScript again, and he‚Äôs back with one of his typical deep dives into a newer ECMAScript feature: import attributes. This feature provides an inline syntax for attaching metadata to module imports such as for importing non-JavaScript modules (e.g. JSON, WASM or¬†CSS).

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

How to Enable End-to-End Testing with Synthetic Monitoring ‚Äî Synthetic Monitoring helps you launch new features with confidence and speed. Learn how you can create robust end-to-end test suites, spend less time on false positives, and proactively catch errors before they get to¬†production.

Datadog sponsor

Node‚Äôs New Built-in Support for TypeScript ‚Äî Node.js v23.6.0 (Current) has just been released and makes Node‚Äôs new type-stripping features work by default, so you can just run node file.ts and it Should Just Work‚Ñ¢. Dr. Axel explains how it works and what the limitations¬†are.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

IN BRIEF:

  • ü•ä The Deno vs Oracle fight over the JavaScript‚Ñ¢ trademark continues as Oracle has informed Deno they're not going to voluntarily relinquish the mark. Deno's job now is to show how JavaScript has long been used as a generic term and hasn't been controlled by Oracle.

  • The Express.js team has posted about the project's recent revival and its plans to push Express.js forward in¬†2025.

  • ‚ùÑÔ∏è The 'WinterCG' Web Interoperable Runtimes Community Group, an effort to promote standards around runtime interoperability of JavaScript runtimes, has moved to Ecma International and is now known as WinterTC (TC55).

  • üì∫ Node.js creator Ryan Dahl gave a talk at GOTO Chicago 2024 about Deno 2, covering Deno's differences to Node and what Deno 2.0 (and JSR) has to offer JavaScript developers, complete with live¬†demos.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10 ‚Äì The efficient npm alternative no longer runs lifecycle scripts of dependencies for security reasons, hashing algorithms have been upgraded to SHA256, and lots of minor¬†tweaks.

  • Bun v1.1.43 ‚Äì The high-performance runtime gets first class S3 support, an HTML bundler, and can output V8 heap snapshots (which is quite something as Bun uses JavaScriptCore, not¬†V8).

  • üî† Tesseract.js 6.0 ‚Äì The popular pure JS multilingual OCR library has resolved a variety of memory leak¬†issues.

  • Docusaurus 3.7 ‚Äì The popular docs-oriented site generator goes full React 19.

  • Node.js v22.13.0 (LTS) ‚Äì The permission model system is now¬†stable.

  • Puppeteer 24.0, RxDB 16.0, Ember 6.1, QuickJS 0.8

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

The Future of htmx ‚Äî htmx is an increasingly popular way to enhance HTML and actually write less JavaScript on the frontend. This post reflects on how htmx would like to be ‚Äòthe new jQuery‚Äô, not least in the sense that one of the project‚Äôs goals is to push the ideas of htmx into the HTML standard itself, as in this set of¬†proposals.

Gross and Petros

You Don't Need Next.js ‚Äî As much as Next.js is considered the React meta-framework of choice, if your requirements are modest, simply going with plain React offers numerous benefits in terms of simplicity and speed, as seen¬†here.

Benny Kok

Introducing Clerk SDKs for Vue and Nuxt ‚Äî Official @clerk/vue & @clerk/nuxt SDKs for authentication integration with pre-built UI components in Vue/Nuxt apps.

Clerk sponsor

Using TypeScript Without Build Tools ‚Äî Chris Coyier enjoys the benefits of TypeScript while developing, but actually compiling it to JavaScript in various scenarios is less endearing. We‚Äôve learnt (above) that Node can now run .ts files directly, but what other projects support the use of TypeScript without build¬†tools?

Chris Coyier

üìÑ Using a JavaScript Component Inside a Haskell App ‚Äì Did you know Haskell‚Äôs main compiler supports integrating with¬†JavaScript? Mateusz Go≈õlinowski

üìÑ Crafting a Dreamy Particle Effect with Three.js and GPGPU Dominik Fojcik

üìÑ Build Your Own Site Speed Testing Tool with Puppeteer Henry Price

üìÑ Sharing a Variable Across HTML, CSS, and JavaScript Chris Coyier

üìÑ Benchmarking GraphQL Solutions in the JS/TS Landscape Tomasz Nie≈ºurawski

üìÑ Shallow Clones vs Structured Clones Phil Nash

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

PostalMime: A Universal Email Parsing Library ‚Äî An email parsing library happy in most JS runtimes. Takes the raw source of emails and parses them into their constituent¬†parts.

Postal Systems

trimMiddle(): The Missing String Trim Method? ‚Äî If you‚Äôve got a long string and want to keep the start and end and truncate in the middle, this is for you. There‚Äôs a live demo here and GitHub¬†repo.

Christian Heilmann

Fully Customizable Form Builder that Blends Seamlessly with Your JS¬†App ‚Äî Need a survey solution you control? With SurveyJS, customize your form builder‚Äôs look and functionality. Try it for¬†free.

SurveyJS sponsor

Introducing @smoores/epub: A Package for Working with EPUB Files ‚Äî EPUB is a popular e-book file format and this new library provides a way to both read and write them. npm package¬†link.

Shane Friedman

Tipex: An Advanced Rich Text Editor for Svelte ‚Äî Based on the popular Tiptap editor framework, it‚Äôs customizable, has theming support, and is Svelte 5-ready. Here‚Äôs a live¬†example.

Friend of Svelte

React-Toastify 11: In-Page Notifications Made Easy ‚Äî There‚Äôs an elaborate demo page here but essentially it‚Äôs a flexible, easy to style ‚Äòtoast‚Äô style notifications system with many years under its belt. GitHub¬†repo.

Fadi Khadra

Electrobun: A New JS Cross-Platform Desktop App Toolkit ‚Äî A fresh take on the concept covered by Electron and Neutralinojs, except based around Bun. It‚Äôs early days, though, with only ARM-based Macs supported for¬†now.

Blackboard Technologies inc.

Tagify 4.33: An Elegant Input Component for Tags ‚Äî The polished demos show a lot of effort has been put in here. GitHub¬†repo.

Yair Even-Or

  • üìä Recharts v2.15.0 ‚Äì D3-powered React chart library now with React 19¬†support.

  • Discordeno 21.0 ‚Äì Discord API library for Node, Deno and¬†Bun.

  • htmlparser2 10.0 ‚Äì Fast and forgiving HTML and XML¬†parser.

  • Ts.ED 8.4 ‚Äì Node + TypeScript framework on top of¬†Express.

  • üìä ApexCharts 4.3 ‚Äì Popular JS charting library.¬†(Demos.)

  • zx 8.3 ‚Äì Google's tool for better Node.js shell¬†scripting.

  • Octokit.js 4.1 ‚Äì 'Batteries-included' GitHub¬†SDK.

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Lattice, Bilt Rewards,¬†etc.

üîπSell to enterprise with a few lines of code with WorkOS ‚Äî the modern, flexible identity platform for B2B SaaS. Integrate SSO, SCIM and FGA in minutes, not¬†months.

üéÅ¬†And one for fun?

üìÑ¬†Play Tetris in a PDF File ‚Äî (direct link to PDF)

I'll let you decide if this one is fun or frightening! Whether or not this will work depends on your PDF reader or browser support, but it works with Chrome and Firefox, at¬†least.

The PDF document format supports embedded JavaScript and this experiment uses it to implement a game of Tetris. The developer, Thomas Rinsma, has used Python to output the PostScript that includes the game's JavaScript. Couple that with the fact many browser PDF renderers are themselves implemented in JavaScript (e.g. PDF.js) and you have a veritable Matryoshka doll of technologies at play¬†here.
